20100405.description: A running service is paused, for example by calling ControlService or ControlServiceEx. Refer to the win_service attribute for details.

20100406.caption: Windows Service Activity: Continue
20100406.description: A paused service is continued, for example by calling ControlService or ControlServiceEx. Refer to the win_service attribute for details.

20100407.caption: Windows Service Activity: Delete
20100407.description: A service is deleted, for example by calling DeleteService. Refer to the win_service attribute for details.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

api.caption: API Details
api.description: Describes details about a typical API (Application Programming Interface) call.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.description: Describes details about the Cloud environment where the event was originally created or logged.

osint.caption: OSINT
osint.description: The OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) object contains details related to an indicator such as the indicator itself, related indicators, geolocation, registrar information, subdomains, analyst commentary, and other contextual information. This information can be used to further enrich a detection or finding by providing decisioning support to other analysts and engineers.

action_id.caption: Action ID
action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The action was unknown. The disposition_id attribute may still be set to a non-unknown value, for example 'Custom Action', 'Challenge'.

1.caption: Allowed
1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.

2.caption: Denied
2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.

3.caption: Observed
3.description: The activity was observed, but neither explicitly allowed nor denied. This is common with IDS and EDR controls that report additional information on observed behavior such as TTPs. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Logged', 'Alert', 'Detected', 'Count', etc.

4.caption: Modified
4.description: The activity was modified, adjusted, or corrected. The disposition_id attribute should be set appropriately, for example 'Restored', 'Corrected', 'Delayed', 'Captcha', 'Tagged'.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The action is not mapped. See the action attribute which contains a data source specific value.

attacks.caption: MITRE ATT&CK® Details
attacks.description: An array of MITRE ATT&CK® objects describing identified tactics, techniques & sub-techniques.

authorizations.caption: Authorization Information
authorizations.description: Provides details about an authorization, such as authorization outcome, and any associated policies related to the activity/event.

confidence.caption: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence, normalized to the caption of the confidence_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidence_id.caption: Confidence ID
confidence_id.description: The normalized confidence refers to the accuracy of the rule that created the finding. A rule with a low confidence means that the finding scope is wide and may create finding reports that may not be malicious in nature.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidence is not mapped to the defined enum values. See the confidence attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

confidence_score.caption: Confidence Score
confidence_score.description: The confidence score as reported by the event source.

disposition.caption: Disposition
disposition.description: The disposition name, normalized to the caption of the disposition_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

disposition_id.caption: Disposition ID
disposition_id.description: Describes the outcome or action taken by a security control, such as access control checks, malware detections or various types of policy violations.

1.caption: Allowed
1.description: Granted access or allowed the action to the protected resource.

2.caption: Blocked
2.description: Denied access or blocked the action to the protected resource.

3.caption: Quarantined
3.description: A suspicious file or other content was moved to a benign location.

4.caption: Isolated
4.description: A session was isolated on the network or within a browser.

5.caption: Deleted
5.description: A file or other content was deleted.

6.caption: Dropped
6.description: The request was detected as a threat and resulted in the connection being dropped.

7.caption: Custom Action
7.description: A custom action was executed such as running of a command script. Use the message attribute of the base class for details.

8.caption: Approved
8.description: A request or submission was approved. For example, when a form was properly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 1 'Allowed'.

9.caption: Restored
9.description: A quarantined file or other content was restored to its original location.

10.caption: Exonerated
10.description: A suspicious or risky entity was deemed to no longer be suspicious (re-scored).

11.caption: Corrected
11.description: A corrupt file or configuration was corrected.

12.caption: Partially Corrected
12.description: A corrupt file or configuration was partially corrected.

13.caption: Uncorrected
13.description: A corrupt file or configuration was not corrected.

14.caption: Delayed
14.description: An operation was delayed, for example if a restart was required to finish the operation.

15.caption: Detected
15.description: Suspicious activity or a policy violation was detected without further action.

16.caption: No Action
16.description: The outcome of an operation had no action taken.

17.caption: Logged
17.description: The operation or action was logged without further action.

18.caption: Tagged
18.description: A file or other entity was marked with extended attributes.

19.caption: Alert
19.description: The request or activity was detected as a threat and resulted in a notification but request was not blocked.

20.caption: Count
20.description: Counted the request or activity but did not determine whether to allow it or block it.

21.caption: Reset
21.description: The request was detected as a threat and resulted in the connection being reset.

22.caption: Captcha
22.description: Required the end user to solve a CAPTCHA puzzle to prove that a human being is sending the request.

23.caption: Challenge
23.description: Ran a silent challenge that required the client session to verify that it's a browser, and not a bot.

24.caption: Access Revoked
24.description: The requestor's access has been revoked due to security policy enforcements. Note: use the Host profile if the User or Actor requestor is not present in the event class.

25.caption: Rejected
25.description: A request or submission was rejected. For example, when a form was improperly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 2 'Blocked'.

26.caption: Unauthorized
26.description: An attempt to access a resource was denied due to an authorization check that failed. This is a more specific disposition than 2 'Blocked' and can be complemented with the authorizations attribute for more detail.

27.caption: Error
27.description: An error occurred during the processing of the activity or request. Use the message attribute of the base class for details.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The disposition is not mapped. See the disposition attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

firewall_rule.caption: Firewall Rule
firewall_rule.description: The firewall rule that pertains to the control that triggered the event, if applicable.

is_alert.caption: Alert
is_alert.description: Indicates that the event is considered to be an alertable signal. Should be set to true if disposition_id = Alert among other dispositions, and/or risk_level_id or severity_id of the event is elevated. Not all control events will be alertable, for example if disposition_id = Exonerated or disposition_id = Allowed.

malware.caption: Malware
malware.description: A list of Malware objects, describing details about the identified malware.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description: The policy that pertains to the control that triggered the event, if applicable. For example the name of an anti-malware policy or an access control policy.

risk_details.caption: Risk Details
risk_details.description: Describes the risk associated with the finding.

risk_level.caption: Risk Level
risk_level.description: The risk level, normalized to the caption of the risk_level_id value.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The risk level is not mapped. See the risk_level attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

risk_score.caption: Risk Score
risk_score.description: The risk score as reported by the event source.

end_time_dt.caption: End Time
end_time_dt.description: The end time of a time period, or the time of the most recent event included in the aggregate event.

start_time_dt.caption: Start Time
start_time_dt.description: The start time of a time period, or the time of the least recent event included in the aggregate event.

time_dt.caption: Event Time
time_dt.description: The normalized event occurrence time or the finding creation time.

windows_service_activity.description: Windows Service Activity events report when a process interacts with the Service Control Manager.

windows_resource_activity.caption: Windows Resource Activity
windows_resource_activity.name: windows_resource_activity

activity_id.caption: Activity ID
activity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the activity that triggered the event.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event activity is not mapped. See the activity_name attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

win_resource.caption: Windows Resource
win_resource.description: The Windows resource object that was accessed, such as a mutant or timer.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: The actor object describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity. Note that this is not the threat actor of a campaign but may be part of a campaign.

device.caption: Device
device.description: An addressable device, computer system or host.

activity_name.caption: Activity
activity_name.description: The event activity name, as defined by the activity_id.

category_name.caption: Category
category_name.description: The event category name, as defined by category_uid value: System Activity.

category_uid.caption: Category ID
category_uid.description: The category unique identifier of the event.

1.caption: System Activity
1.description: System Activity events.

class_name.caption: Class
class_name.description: The event class name, as defined by class_uid value: Windows Resource Activity.

class_uid.caption: Class ID
class_uid.description: The unique identifier of a class. A class describes the attributes available in an event.

201003.caption: Windows Resource Activity
201003.description: Windows Resource Activity events report when a process accesses a Windows managed resource object, successful or otherwise.

count.caption: Count
count.description: The number of times that events in the same logical group occurred during the event Start Time to End Time period.

duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds
duration.description: The event duration or aggregate time, the amount of time the event covers from start_time to end_time in milliseconds.

end_time.caption: End Time
end_time.description: The end time of a time period, or the time of the most recent event included in the aggregate event.

enrichments.caption: Enrichments
enrichments.description:
The additional information from an external data source, which is associated with the event or a finding. For example add location information for the IP address in the DNS answers:

[{"name": "answers.ip", "value": "92.24.47.250", "type": "location", "data": {"city": "Socotra", "continent": "Asia", "coordinates": [-25.4153, 17.0743], "country": "YE", "desc": "Yemen"}}]

message.caption: Message
message.description: The description of the event/finding, as defined by the source.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The metadata associated with the event or a finding.

observables.caption: Observables
observables.description: The observables associated with the event or a finding.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

severity.caption: Severity
severity.description: The event/finding severity, normalized to the caption of the severity_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

severity_id.caption: Severity ID
severity_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the event/finding severity.

The normalized severity is a measurement the effort and expense required to manage and resolve an event or incident. Smaller numerical values represent lower impact events, and larger numerical values represent higher impact events.

1.caption: Informational
1.description: Informational message. No action required.

2.caption: Low
2.description: The user decides if action is needed.

3.caption: Medium
3.description: Action is required but the situation is not serious at this time.

4.caption: High
4.description: Action is required immediately.

5.caption: Critical
5.description: Action is required immediately and the scope is broad.

6.caption: Fatal
6.description: An error occurred but it is too late to take remedial action.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event/finding severity is not mapped. See the severity attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

start_time.caption: Start Time
start_time.description: The start time of a time period, or the time of the least recent event included in the aggregate event.

status.caption: Status
status.description: The event status, normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

status_code.caption: Status Code
status_code.description:
The event status code, as reported by the event source.

For example, in a Windows Failed Authentication event, this would be the value of 'Failure Code', e.g. 0x18.

status_detail.caption: Status Detail
status_detail.description: The status detail contains additional information about the event/finding outcome.

status_id.caption: Status ID
status_id.description: The normalized identifier of the event status.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event status is not mapped. See the status attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

time.caption: Event Time
time.description: The normalized event occurrence time or the finding creation time.

timezone_offset.caption: Timezone Offset
timezone_offset.description: The number of minutes that the reported event time is ahead or behind UTC, in the range -1,080 to +1,080.

type_name.caption: Type Name
type_name.description: The event/finding type name, as defined by the type_uid.

type_uid.caption: Type ID
type_uid.description: The event/finding type ID. It identifies the event's semantics and structure. The value is calculated by the logging system as: class_uid * 100 + activity_id.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

api.description: Describes details about a typical API (Application Programming Interface) call.

cloud.description: Describes details about the Cloud environment where the event was originally created or logged.

http_cookie.caption: HTTP Cookie
http_cookie.name: http_cookie
http_cookie.description: The HTTP Cookie object, also known as a web cookie or browser cookie, contains details and values pertaining to a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. This data is then stored by the browser and sent back to the server with subsequent requests, allowing the server to remember and track certain information about the user's browsing session or preferences.

domain.caption: Domain
domain.description: The domain name for the server from which the http_cookie is served.

expiration_time.caption: Expiration Time
expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.

http_only.caption: HTTP Only
http_only.description: A cookie attribute to make it inaccessible via JavaScript

is_http_only.caption: HTTP Only
is_http_only.description: This attribute prevents the cookie from being accessed via JavaScript.

is_secure.caption: Secure
is_secure.description: The cookie attribute indicates that cookies are sent to the server only when the request is encrypted using the HTTPS protocol.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The HTTP cookie name.

path.caption: Path
path.description: The path of the HTTP cookie.

samesite.caption: SameSite
samesite.description: The cookie attribute that lets servers specify whether/when cookies are sent with cross-site requests. Values are: Strict, Lax or None

secure.caption: Secure
secure.description: The cookie attribute to only send cookies to the server with an encrypted request over the HTTPS protocol.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

expiration_time_dt.caption: Expiration Time
expiration_time_dt.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.

encryption_details.caption: Encryption Details

encryption_details.description: Details about the encrytpion methodology utilized.

algorithm.description: The encryption algorithm used, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id

1.caption: DES
1.description: Data Encryption Standard Algorithm

2.caption: TripleDES
2.description: Triple Data Encryption Standard Algorithm

3.caption: AES
3.description: Advanced Encryption Standard Algorithm.

4.caption: RSA
4.description: Rivest-Shamir-Adleman Algorithm

5.caption: ECC
5.description: Elliptic Curve Cryptography Algorithm

6.caption: SM2
6.description: ShangMi Cryptographic Algorithm

99.caption: Other
99.description: The algorithm is not mapped. See the algorithm attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

key_length.caption: Encryption Key Length
key_length.description: The length of the encryption key used.

key_uid.caption: Key UID
key_uid.description: The unique identifier of the key used for encrpytion. For example, AWS KMS Key ARN.

type.caption: Encryption Type
type.description: The type of the encryption used.

raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

request.caption: Request Elements
request.name: request
request.description: The Request Elements object describes characteristics of an API request.

containers.caption: Containers
containers.description: When working with containerized applications, the set of containers which write to the standard the output of a particular logging driver. For example, this may be the set of containers involved in handling api requests and responses for a containerized application.

data.caption: Data
data.description: The additional data that is associated with the api request.

flags.caption: Flags
flags.description: The communication flags that are associated with the api request.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique request identifier.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

whois.caption: WHOIS
whois.name: whois
whois.description: The resources of a WHOIS record for a given domain. This can include domain names, IP address blocks, autonomous system information, and/or contact and registration information for a domain.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: The autonomous system information associated with a domain.

created_time.caption: Registered At
created_time.description: When the domain was registered or WHOIS entry was created.

dnssec_status_id.caption: DNSSEC Status ID
dnssec_status_id.description: Describes the normalized status of DNS Security Extensions (DNSSEC) for a domain.

1.caption: Signed
1.description: The related domain enables the signing of DNS records using DNSSEC.

2.caption: Unsigned
2.description: The related domain does not enable the signing of DNS records using DNSSEC.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The DNSSEC status is not mapped. See the dnssec_status attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

domain.caption: Domain
domain.description: The domain name corresponding to the WHOIS record.

email_addr.caption: Registrar Abuse Email Address
email_addr.description: The email address for the registrar's abuse contact

last_seen_time.caption: Last Updated At
last_seen_time.description: When the WHOIS record was last updated or seen at.

name_servers.caption: Name Servers
name_servers.description: A collection of name servers related to a domain registration or other record.

phone_number.caption: Registrar Abuse Phone Number
phone_number.description: The phone number for the registrar's abuse contact

status.caption: Domain Status
status.description: The status of a domain and its ability to be transferred, e.g., clientTransferProhibited.

subdomains.caption: Subdomains
subdomains.description: An array of subdomain strings. Can be used to collect several subdomains such as those from Domain Generation Algorithms (DGAs).

subnet.caption: Subnet Block
subnet.description: The IP address block (CIDR) associated with a domain.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

created_time_dt.description: When the domain was registered or WHOIS entry was created.

last_seen_time_dt.caption: Last Updated At
last_seen_time_dt.description: When the WHOIS record was last updated or seen at.

web_resource.caption: Web Resource
web_resource.name: web_resource
web_resource.description: The Web Resource object describes characteristics of a web resource that was affected by the activity/event.

data.caption: Data
data.description: Details of the web resource, e.g, file details, search results or application-defined resource.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: Description of the web resource.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the web resource.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The web resource type as defined by the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the web resource.

url_string.caption: URL String

policy.caption: Policy
policy.name: policy
policy.description:
The Policy object describes the policies that are applicable.

Policy attributes provide traceability to the operational state of the security product at the time that the event was captured, facilitating forensics, troubleshooting, and policy tuning/adjustments.

data.caption: Data
data.description: Additional data about the policy such as the underlying JSON policy itself or other details.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the policy.

is_applied.caption: Applied
is_applied.description: A determination if the content of a policy was applied to a target or request, or not.

name.caption: Name

uid.caption: Unique ID

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

trace.caption: Trace
trace.name: trace
trace.description: The trace object contains information about a distributed trace,  which is crucial for observability. Traces are made up of one or more spans, which are individual units of work in application activity. Traces track the journey of a request as it moves through various services in a system, capturing key details like timing, status, and dependencies at each step. Traces provide insights into system performance, helping to identify latency, bottlenecks, and issues in complex, distributed environments.

duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds
duration.description: The total time, in milliseconds, that the trace covers, calculated as the difference between start_time and end_time. This duration helps assess the overall performance of a request as it travels across various services, and is essential for identifying latency and potential bottlenecks within the distributed system. The trace duration may differ from individual span durations due to the propagation and processing times of the trace as it spans multiple components.

end_time.caption: End Time
end_time.description: The end timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track overall performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

flags.caption: Flags
flags.description: The flags associated with the trace, used to indicate specific properties or behaviors, such as whether the trace is sampled or if it has special handling. Flags help control how traces are processed, logged, and analyzed, providing valuable context for tracing and observability tools in identifying trace characteristics or specific tracking requirements.

service.caption: Service
service.description: Identifies the service or component generating the trace, helping to track and correlate the flow of requests through various parts of a distributed system. This information is essential for understanding the role and performance of specific services within the broader context of system operations and for diagnosing issues across different components.

span.caption: Span
span.description: Represents a single unit of work or operation within a distributed trace. A span typically tracks the execution of a request across a service, capturing important details such as the operation, timestamps, and status. Spans help break down the overall trace into smaller, manageable parts, enabling detailed analysis of the performance and behavior of specific operations within the system. They are crucial for understanding latency, dependencies, and bottlenecks in complex distributed systems.

start_time.caption: Start Time
start_time.description: The start timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the end time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time enables accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the trace used in distributed systems and microservices architecture to track and correlate requests across various components of an application.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

end_time_dt.description: The end timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Normalized time allows for accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track overall performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

Normalized time enables accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

data_security.caption: Data Security
data_security.name: data_security
data_security.description: The Data Security object describes the characteristics, techniques and content of a Data Loss Prevention (DLP), Data Loss Detection (DLD), Data Classification, or similar tools' finding, alert, or detection mechanism(s).

data_lifecycle_state.caption: Data Lifecycle State
data_lifecycle_state.description: The name of the stage or state that the data was in. E.g., Data-at-Rest, Data-in-Transit, etc.

data_lifecycle_state_id.caption: Data Lifecycle State ID
data_lifecycle_state_id.description: The stage or state that the data was in when it was assessed or scanned by a data security tool.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The data lifecycle state is unknown.

1.caption: Data at-Rest
1.description: The data was stored on physical or logical media and was not actively moving through the network nor was being processed. E.g., data stored in a database, PDF files in a file share, or EHR records in object storage.

2.caption: Data in-Transit
2.description: The data was actively moving through the network or from one physical or logical location to another. E.g., emails being send, data replication or Change Data Capture (CDC) streams, or sensitive data processed on an API.

3.caption: Data in-Use
3.description: The data was being processed, accessed, or read by a system, making it active in memory or CPU. E.g., sensitive data in a Business Intelligence tool, ePHI being processed in an EHR application or a user viewing data stored in a spreadsheet or PDF.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The data lifecycle state is not mapped. See the data_lifecycle_state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

detection_pattern.caption: Detection Pattern
detection_pattern.description: Specific pattern, algorithm, fingerprint, or model used for detection.

detection_system.caption: Detection System
detection_system.description: The name of the type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from. E.g., Endpoint, Secure Email Gateway, etc.

detection_system_id.caption: Detection System ID
detection_system_id.description: The type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the detection_system attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Endpoint
1.description: A dedicated agent or sensor installed on a device, either a dedicated data security tool or an Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Symantec DLP, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MDE).

2.caption: DLP Gateway
2.description: A Data Loss Prevention (DLP) gateway that is positioned in-line of an information store such as a network share, a database, or otherwise that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.

3.caption: Mobile Device Management
3.description: A Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on mobile devices (e.g., cellphones, tablets, End User Devices [EUDs]).

4.caption: Data Discovery & Classification
4.description: A tool that actively identifies and classifies sensitive data in digital media and information stores in accordance with a policy or automated functionality. E.g, Amazon Macie, Microsoft Purview.

5.caption: Secure Web Gateway
5.description: A Secure Web Gateway (SWG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies at a network-edge such as within a proxy or firewall service.

6.caption: Secure Email Gateway
6.description: A Secure Email Gateway (SEG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies within email systems. E.g., Microsoft Defender for Office, Google Workspaces.

7.caption: Digital Rights Management
7.description: A Digital Rights Management (DRM) or a dedicated Information Rights Management (IRM) are tools which can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on digital media via policy or user access rights.

8.caption: Cloud Access Security Broker
8.description: A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies in-line to cloud systems such as the public cloud or Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) tool. E.g., Forcepoint CASB, SkyHigh Security.

9.caption: Database Activity Monitoring
9.description: A Database Activity Monitoring (DAM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies as part of a dedicated database or warehouse monitoring solution.

10.caption: Application-Level DLP
10.description: A built in Data Loss Prevention (DLP) or other data security capability within a tool or platform such as an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) or Customer Relations Management (CRM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.

11.caption: Developer Security
11.description: Any Developer Security tool such as an Infrastructure-as-Code (IAC) security scanner, Secrets Detection, or Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SSDLC) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., TruffleHog, GitGuardian, Git-Secrets.

12.caption: Data Security Posture Management
12.description: A Data Security Posture Management (DSPM) tool is a continuous monitoring and data discovery solution that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies for local and cloud environments. E.g., Cyera, Sentra, IBM Polar Security.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of detection system or a multi-variate system made up of several other systems.

pattern_match.caption: Pattern Match
pattern_match.description: A text, binary, file name, or datastore that matched against a detection rule.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description: Details about the policy that triggered the finding.

category.caption: Category
category.description: The name of the data classification category that data matched into, e.g. Financial, Personal, Governmental, etc.

category_id.caption: Category ID
category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the data classification category.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Personal
1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.

2.caption: Governmental
2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.

3.caption: Financial
3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.

4.caption: Business
4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.

5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement
5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.

6.caption: Security
6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.

classifier_details.caption: Classifier Details
classifier_details.description: Describes details about the classifier used for data classification.

confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality
confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID
confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

discovery_details.caption: Discovery Details
discovery_details.description: Details about the data discovered by classification job.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The source URL pointing towards the full classifcation job details.

status.caption: Status
status.description: The resultant status of the classification job normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

1.description: The classification job completed for the evaluated resource.

total.description: The total count of discovered entities, by the classification job.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

dmarc_override.description: The Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) override action.

dmarc_policy.caption: DMARC Policy
dmarc_policy.description: The Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) policy status.

spf.caption: SPF Status
spf.description: The Sender Policy Framework (SPF) status of the email.

raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

span.caption: Span
span.name: span
span.description: Represents a single unit of work or operation within a distributed trace. A span typically tracks the execution of a request across a service, capturing important details such as the operation, timestamps, and status. Spans help break down the overall trace into smaller, manageable parts, enabling detailed analysis of the performance and behavior of specific operations within the system. They are crucial for understanding latency, dependencies, and bottlenecks in complex distributed systems.

duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds
duration.description: The total time, in milliseconds, that the span represents, calculated as the difference between start_time and end_time. It reflects the operation's performance and latency, independent of event timestamps, and accounts for normalized times used by observability tools to ensure consistency across distributed systems.

end_time.caption: End Time
end_time.description: The end timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the observability system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

message.caption: Message
message.description: The message in a span (often refered to as a span event) serves as a way to record significant moments or occurrences during the span's lifecycle. This content typically manifests as log entries, annotations, or semi-structured events as a string, providing additional granularity and context about what happens at specific points during the execution of an operation.

operation.caption: Operation
operation.description: Describes an action performed in a span, such as API requests, database queries, or computations.

parent_uid.caption: Parent Unique ID
parent_uid.description: The ID of the parent span for this span object, establishing its relationship in the trace hierarchy.

service.caption: Service
service.description: Identifies the service or component that generates the span, helping trace its path through the distributed system.

start_time.caption: Start Time
start_time.description: The start timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. This timestamp is normalized across the observability system, ensuring consistency even when events occur across distributed services with potentially unsynchronized clocks. By using normalized time, observability tools can provide accurate, uniform measurements of operation performance and latency, regardless of where or when the events actually occur.

status_code.caption: Status Code
status_code.description: Indicates the outcome of the operation in the span, such as success, failure, or error. Issues in a span typically refer to problems such as failed operations, timeouts, service unavailability, or errors in processing that can negatively impact the performance or reliability of the system. Tracking the `status_code` helps pinpoint these issues, enabling quicker identification and resolution of system inefficiencies or faults.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier for the span, used in distributed systems and microservices architectures to track and correlate requests across different components of an application. It enables tracing the flow of a request through various services.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

end_time_dt.caption: End Time
end_time_dt.description: The end timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the observability system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

start_time_dt.caption: Start Time
start_time_dt.description: The start timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. This timestamp is normalized across the observability system, ensuring consistency even when events occur across distributed services with potentially unsynchronized clocks. By using normalized time, observability tools can provide accurate, uniform measurements of operation performance and latency, regardless of where or when the events actually occur.

software_component.caption: Software Component
software_component.name: software_component
software_component.description: The Software Component object describes characteristics of a software component within a software package.

author.caption: Author
author.description: The author(s) who published the software component.

hash.caption: Hash
hash.description: Cryptographic hash to identify the binary instance of a software component.

license.caption: Software License
license.description: The software license applied to this component.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The software component name.

purl.caption: Package URL
purl.description: The Package URL (PURL) to identify the software component. This is a URL that uniquely identifies the component, including the component's name, version, and type. The URL is used to locate and retrieve the component's metadata and content.

related_component.caption: Related Component
related_component.description: The package URL (PURL) of the component that this software component has a relationship with.

relationship.caption: Relationship
relationship.description: The relationship between two software components, normalized to the caption of the relationship_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

relationship_id.caption: Relationship ID
relationship_id.description: The normalized identifier of the relationship between two software components.

1.description: The component is a dependency of another component. Can be used to define both direct and transitive dependencies.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The relationship is not mapped. See the relationship attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of software component, normalized to the caption of the type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

1.caption: Framework
1.description: A software framework.

2.caption: Library
2.description: A software library.

3.description: An operating system. Useful for SBOMs of container images.

99.caption: Other

raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

network_traffic.description: The Network Traffic object describes characteristics of network traffic. Network traffic refers to data moving across a network at a given point of time.

alert.description: The integer value of TLS alert if present. The alerts are defined in the TLS specification in RFC-2246.

certificate.caption: Certificate
certificate.description: The certificate object containing information about the digital certificate.

certificate_chain.caption: Certificate Chain
certificate_chain.description: The Chain of Certificate Serial Numbers field provides a chain of Certificate Issuer Serial Numbers leading to the Root Certificate Issuer.

client_ciphers.caption: Client Cipher Suites
client_ciphers.description: The client cipher suites that were exchanged during the TLS handshake negotiation.

handshake_dur.caption: Handshake Duration

server_ciphers.caption: Server Cipher Suites
server_ciphers.description: The server cipher suites that were exchanged during the TLS handshake negotiation.
