unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.name: cloud
cloud.description: The Cloud object contains information about a cloud or Software-as-a-Service account or similar construct, such as AWS Account ID, regions, organizations, folders, compartments, tenants, etc.

account.caption: Account
account.description: The account object describes details about the account that was the source or target of the activity.

cloud_partition.caption: Cloud Partition
cloud_partition.description: The canonical cloud partition name to which the region is assigned (e.g. AWS Partitions: aws, aws-cn, aws-us-gov).

org.caption: Organization
org.description: Organization and org unit relevant to the event or object.

project_uid.caption: Project ID
project_uid.description: The unique identifier of a Cloud project.

provider.caption: Provider
provider.description: The unique name of the Cloud services provider, such as AWS, MS Azure, GCP, etc.

region.caption: Region
region.description: The name of the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

zone.caption: Network Zone
zone.description: The availability zone in the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

file.caption: File
file.name: file
file.description: The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details.

accessed_time.caption: Accessed Time
accessed_time.description: The time when the file was last accessed.

accessor.caption: Accessor
accessor.description: The name of the user who last accessed the object.

attributes.caption: Attributes
attributes.description: The bitmask value that represents the file attributes.

company_name.caption: Company Name
company_name.description: The name of the company that published the file. For example: Microsoft Corporation.

confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality
confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID
confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the file was created.

creator.caption: Creator
creator.description: The user that created the file.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the file, as returned by file system. For example: the description as returned by the Unix file command or the Windows file type.

drive_type.caption: Drive Type
drive_type.description: The drive type, normalized to the caption of the drive_type_id value. In the case of Other, it is defined by the source.

drive_type_id.caption: Drive Type ID
drive_type_id.description: Identifies the type of a disk drive, i.e. fixed, removable, etc.

1.caption: Removable
1.description: The drive has removable media; for example, a floppy drive, thumb drive, or flash card reader.

2.caption: Fixed
2.description: The drive has fixed media; for example, a hard disk drive or flash drive.

3.caption: Remote
3.description: The drive is a remote (network) drive.

4.caption: CD-ROM
4.description: The drive is a CD-ROM drive.

5.caption: RAM Disk
5.description: The drive is a RAM disk.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The drive type is not mapped. See the drive_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

encryption_details.caption: Encryption Details
encryption_details.description: The encryption details of the file. Should be populated if the file is encrypted.

ext.caption: File Extension
ext.description: The extension of the file, excluding the leading dot. For example: exe from svchost.exe, or gz from export.tar.gz.

internal_name.caption: Internal Name
internal_name.description: The name of the file as identified within the file itself. This contrasts with the name by which the file is known on disk. Where available, the internal name is widely used by security practitioners and detection content because the on-disk file name is not reliable. On the Windows OS, most PE files contain a VERSIONINFO resource from which the internal name can be obtained. On macOS, binaries can optionally embed a copy of the application's Info.plist file which in turn contains the name of the executable.

is_deleted.caption: Deleted
is_deleted.description: Indicates if the file was deleted from the filesystem.

is_encrypted.caption: Encrypted
is_encrypted.description: Indicates if the file is encrypted.

is_public.caption: Public
is_public.description: Indicates if the file is publicly accessible. For example in an object's public access in AWS S3

is_system.caption: System
is_system.description: The indication of whether the object is part of the operating system.

mime_type.caption: MIME type
mime_type.description: The Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) type of the file, if applicable.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the file was last modified.

modifier.caption: Modifier
modifier.description: The user that last modified the file.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the file. For example: svchost.exe

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The user that owns the file/object.

parent_folder.caption: Parent Folder
parent_folder.description: The parent folder in which the file resides. For example: c:\windows\system32

path.caption: Path
path.description: The full path to the file. For example: c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product that created or installed the file.

signature.caption: Digital Signature
signature.description: The digital signature of the file.

size.caption: Size
size.description: The size of data, in bytes.

storage_class.caption: Storage Class
storage_class.description: The storage class of the file. For example in AWS S3: STANDARD, STANDARD_IA, GLACIER.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the file.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The file type.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the file as defined by the storage system, such the file system file ID.

url.caption: URL
url.description: The URL of the file, when applicable.

xattributes.caption: Extended Attributes
xattributes.description:
An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs where each pair represents a file or folder extended attribute.

For example: Windows alternate data stream attributes (ADS stream name, ADS size, etc.), user-defined or application-defined attributes, ACL, owner, primary group, etc. Examples from DCS:

  • ads_name
  • ads_size
  • dacl
  • owner
  • primary_group
  • link_name - name of the link associated to the file.
  • hard_link_count - the number of links that are associated to the file.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

accessed_time_dt.caption: Accessed Time
accessed_time_dt.description: The time when the file was last accessed.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The time when the file was created.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The time when the file was last modified.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.name: actor
actor.description: The Actor object contains details about the user, role, application, service, or process that initiated or performed a specific activity. Note that Actor is not the threat actor of a campaign but may be part of a campaign.

app_name.caption: Application Name
app_name.description: The client application or service that initiated the activity. This can be in conjunction with the user if present. Note that app_name is distinct from the process if present.

app_uid.caption: Application ID
app_uid.description: The unique identifier of the client application or service that initiated the activity. This can be in conjunction with the user if present. Note that app_name is distinct from the process.pid or process.uid if present.

authorizations.caption: Authorization Information
authorizations.description: Provides details about an authorization, such as authorization outcome, and any associated policies related to the activity/event.

idp.caption: Identity Provider
idp.description: This object describes details about the Identity Provider used.

invoked_by.caption: Invoked by
invoked_by.description: The name of the service that invoked the activity as described in the event.

process.caption: Process
process.description: The process that initiated the activity.

session.caption: Session
session.description: The user session from which the activity was initiated.

user.caption: User
user.description: The user that initiated the activity or the user context from which the activity was initiated.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

sbom.caption: Software Bill of Materials
sbom.name: sbom
sbom.description: The Software Bill of Materials object describes characteristics of a generated SBOM.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the SBOM was created.

package.caption: Software Package
package.description: The device software that is being discovered by an inventory process.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product that generated the SBOM e.g. cdxgen or Syft.

software_components.caption: Software Components
software_components.description: The list of software components used in the software package.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The time when the SBOM was created.

service.caption: Service
service.name: service
service.description: The Service object describes characteristics of a service, e.g. AWS EC2.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels associated with the service.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the service.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the service.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the service.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

epss.caption: EPSS
epss.name: epss
epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The timestamp indicating when the EPSS score was calculated.

percentile.caption: EPSS Percentile
percentile.description: The EPSS score's percentile representing relative importance and ranking of the score in the larger EPSS dataset.

score.caption: EPPS Score
score.description: The EPSS score representing the probability [0-1] of exploitation in the wild in the next 30 days (following score publication).

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the EPSS model used to calculate the score.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The timestamp indicating when the EPSS score was calculated.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.name: metadata
metadata.description: The Metadata object describes the metadata associated with the event.

correlation_uid.caption: Correlation UID
correlation_uid.description: The unique identifier used to correlate events.

debug.caption: Debug Information
debug.description: Debug information about non-fatal issues with this OCSF event. Each issue is a line in this string array.

event_code.caption: Event Code
event_code.description: The Event ID, Code, or Name that the product uses to primarily identify the event.

extension.caption: Schema Extension
extension.description: The schema extension used to create the event.

extensions.caption: Schema Extensions
extensions.description: The schema extensions used to create the event.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels attached to the event. For example: ["sample", "dev"]

log_level.caption: Log Level
log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.

log_name.caption: Log Name
log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.

log_provider.caption: Log Provider
log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.

log_version.caption: Log Version
log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.

logged_time.caption: Logged Time
logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

loggers.caption: Loggers
loggers.description: An array of Logger objects that describe the devices and logging products between the event source and its eventual destination. Note, this attribute can be used when there is a complex end-to-end path of event flow.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

original_time.caption: Original Time
original_time.description: The original event time as reported by the event source. For example, the time in the original format from system event log such as Syslog on Unix/Linux and the System event file on Windows. Omit if event is generated instead of collected via logs.

processed_time.caption: Processed Time
processed_time.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product that reported the event.

profiles.caption: Profiles
profiles.description: The list of profiles used to create the event. Profiles should be referenced by their name attribute for core profiles, or extension/name for profiles from extensions.

sequence.caption: Sequence Number
sequence.description: Sequence number of the event. The sequence number is a value available in some events, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the event time precision.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the event.

uid.caption: Event UID
uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

logged_time_dt.caption: Logged Time
logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

processed_time_dt.caption: Processed Time
processed_time_dt.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.

sso.caption: SSO
sso.name: sso
sso.description: The Single Sign-On (SSO) object provides a structure for normalizing SSO attributes, configuration, and/or settings from Identity Providers.

auth_protocol.caption: Auth Protocol
auth_protocol.description: The authorization protocol as defined by the caption of auth_protocol_id. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.

auth_protocol_id.caption: Auth Protocol ID
auth_protocol_id.description: The normalized identifier of the authentication protocol used by the SSO resource.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The authentication protocol is not mapped. See the auth_protocol attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

certificate.caption: SAML Certificate
certificate.description: Digital Signature associated with the SSO resource, e.g., SAML X.509 certificate details.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: When the SSO resource was created.

duration_mins.caption: SSO Session Duration
duration_mins.description: The duration (in minutes) for an SSO session, after which re-authentication is required.

idle_timeout.caption: SSO Idle Timeout
idle_timeout.description: Duration (in minutes) of allowed inactivity before Single Sign-On (SSO) session expiration.

login_endpoint.caption: SSO Login Endpoint
login_endpoint.description: URL for initiating an SSO login request.

logout_endpoint.caption: SSO Logout Endpoint
logout_endpoint.description: URL for initiating an SSO logout request, allowing sessions to be terminated across applications.

metadata_endpoint.caption: SSO Metadata Endpoint
metadata_endpoint.description: URL where metadata about the SSO configuration is available (e.g., for SAML configurations).

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The most recent time when the SSO resource was updated.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the SSO resource.

protocol_name.caption: Supported Protocol
protocol_name.description: The supported protocol for the SSO resource. E.g., SAML or OIDC.

scopes.caption: Scopes
scopes.description: Scopes define the specific permissions or actions that the client is allowed to perform on behalf of the user. Each scope represents a different set of permissions, and the user can selectively grant or deny access to specific scopes during the authorization process.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: A unique identifier for a SSO resource.

vendor_name.caption: Service Provider
vendor_name.description: Name of the vendor or service provider implementing SSO. E.g., Okta, Auth0, Microsoft.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: When the SSO resource was created.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The most recent time when the SSO resource was updated.

kernel_driver.caption: Kernel Extension
kernel_driver.name: kernel_driver
kernel_driver.description: The Kernel Extension object describes a kernel driver that has been loaded or unloaded into the operating system (OS) kernel.

file.caption: File
file.description: The driver/extension file object.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint
fingerprint.name: fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.

algorithm.caption: Algorithm
algorithm.description: The hash algorithm used to create the digital fingerprint, normalized to the caption of algorithm_id. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.

algorithm_id.caption: Algorithm ID
algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized hash algorithm, which was used to create the digital fingerprint.

1.caption: MD5
1.description: MD5 message-digest algorithm producing a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value.

2.caption: SHA-1
2.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 1 producing a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value.

3.caption: SHA-256
3.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 256-bit (32-byte) hash value.

4.caption: SHA-512
4.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 512-bit (64-byte) hash value.

5.caption: CTPH
5.description: The ssdeep generated fuzzy checksum. Also known as Context Triggered Piecewise Hash (CTPH).

6.caption: TLSH
6.description: The TLSH fuzzy hashing algorithm.

7.caption: quickXorHash
7.description: Microsoft simple non-cryptographic hash algorithm that works by XORing the bytes in a circular-shifting fashion.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The algorithm is not mapped. See the algorithm attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

agent.caption: Agent
agent.name: agent
agent.description: An Agent (also known as a Sensor) is typically installed on an Operating System (OS) and serves as a specialized software component that can be designed to monitor, detect, collect, archive, or take action. These activities and possible actions are defined by the upstream system controlling the Agent and its intended purpose. For instance, an Agent can include Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) agents, backup/disaster recovery sensors, Application Performance Monitoring or profiling sensors, and similar software.

name.caption: Agent Name
name.description: The name of the agent or sensor. For example: AWS SSM Agent.

policies.caption: Agent Policies
policies.description: Describes the various policies that may be applied or enforced by an agent or sensor. E.g., Conditional Access, prevention, auto-update, tamper protection, destination configuration, etc.

type.caption: Agent Type
type.description: The normalized caption of the type_id value for the agent or sensor. In the case of 'Other' or 'Unknown', it is defined by the event source.

type_id.caption: Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized representation of an agent or sensor. E.g., EDR, vulnerability management, APM, backup & recovery, etc.

1.caption: Endpoint Detection and Response
1.description: Any EDR sensor or agent. Or any tool that provides similar threat detection, anti-malware, anti-ransomware, or similar capabilities. E.g., Crowdstrike Falcon, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, Wazuh.

2.caption: Data Loss Prevention
2.description: Any DLP sensor or agent. Or any tool that provides similar data classification, data loss detection, and/or data loss prevention capabilities. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Microsoft Purview, Symantec DLP.

3.caption: Backup & Recovery
3.description: Any agent or sensor that provides backups, archival, or recovery capabilities. E.g., Azure Backup, AWS Backint Agent.

4.caption: Performance Monitoring & Observability
4.description: Any agent or sensor that provides Application Performance Monitoring (APM), active tracing, profiling, or other observability use cases and optionally forwards the logs. E.g., New Relic Agent, Datadog Agent, Azure Monitor Agent.

5.caption: Vulnerability Management
5.description: Any agent or sensor that provides vulnerability management or scanning capabilities. E.g., Qualys VMDR, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, Crowdstrike Spotlight, Amazon Inspector Agent.

6.caption: Log Forwarding
6.description: Any agent or sensor that forwards logs to a 3rd party storage system such as a data lake or SIEM. E.g., Splunk Universal Forwarder, Tenzir, FluentBit, Amazon CloudWatch Agent, Amazon Kinesis Agent.

7.caption: Mobile Device Management
7.description: Any agent or sensor responsible for providing Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Mobile Enterprise Management (MEM) capabilities. E.g., JumpCloud Agent, Esper Agent, Jamf Pro binary.

8.caption: Configuration Management
8.description: Any agent or sensor that provides configuration management of a device, such as scanning for software, license management, or applying configurations. E.g., AWS Systems Manager Agent, Flexera, ServiceNow MID Server.

9.caption: Remote Access
9.description: Any agent or sensor that provides remote access capabilities to a device. E.g., BeyondTrust, Amazon Systems Manager Agent, Verkada Agent.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

uid.caption: Agent ID
uid.description: The UID of the agent or sensor, sometimes known as a Sensor ID or aid.

uid_alt.caption: Alternate Agent ID
uid_alt.description: An alternative or contextual identifier for the agent or sensor, such as a configuration, organization, or license UID.

vendor_name.caption: Vendor Name
vendor_name.description: The company or author who created the agent or sensor. For example: Crowdstrike.

version.caption: Agent Version
version.description: The semantic version of the agent or sensor, e.g., 7.101.50.0.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.name: autonomous_system
autonomous_system.description: An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain that presents a common, clearly defined routing policy to the internet.

name.caption: Name
name.description: Organization name for the Autonomous System.

number.caption: Number
number.description: Unique number that the AS is identified by.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

network_connection_info.caption: Network Connection Information
network_connection_info.name: network_connection_info
network_connection_info.description: The Network Connection Information object describes characteristics of an OSI Transport Layer communication, including TCP and UDP.

boundary.caption: Boundary
boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID
boundary_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

1.caption: Localhost
1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

2.caption: Internal
2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

3.caption: External
3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.

4.caption: Same VPC
4.description: Through another resource in the same VPC

5.caption: Internet/VPC Gateway
5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway
6.description: Through a virtual private gateway

7.caption: Intra-region VPC
7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.caption: Inter-region VPC
8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

9.caption: Local Gateway
9.description: Through a local gateway

10.caption: Gateway VPC
10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

11.caption: Internet Gateway
11.description: Through an Internet gateway (Nitro-based instances only)

99.caption: Other
99.description: The boundary is not mapped. See the boundary attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

community_uid.caption: Community ID
community_uid.description: The Community ID of the network connection.

direction.caption: Direction
direction.description: The direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

direction_id.caption: Direction ID
direction_id.description: The normalized identifier of the direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email.

1.caption: Inbound
1.description: Inbound network connection. The connection was originated from the Internet or outside network, destined for services on the inside network.

2.caption: Outbound
2.description: Outbound network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the Internet or outside network.

3.caption: Lateral
3.description: Lateral network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the inside network.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The direction is not mapped. See the direction attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

flag_history.caption: Connection Flag History
flag_history.description: The Connection Flag History summarizes events in a network connection. For example flags ShAD representing SYN, SYN/ACK, ACK and Data exchange.

protocol_name.caption: Protocol Name
protocol_name.description: The IP protocol name in lowercase, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: tcp or udp.

protocol_num.caption: Protocol Number
protocol_num.description: The IP protocol number, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: 6 for TCP and 17 for UDP.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The protocol version is not mapped. See the protocol_ver attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

session.caption: Session
session.description: The authenticated user or service session.

tcp_flags.caption: TCP Flags
tcp_flags.description: The network connection TCP header flags (i.e., control bits).

uid.caption: Connection UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

authorization.caption: Authorization Result
authorization.name: authorization
authorization.description: The Authorization Result object provides details about the authorization outcome and associated policies related to activity.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description: Details about the Identity/Access management policies that are applicable.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

d3f_tactic.caption: MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic
d3f_tactic.name: d3f_tactic
d3f_tactic.description: The MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated to an attack

name.caption: Name
name.description: The tactic name that is associated with the defensive technique. For example: Isolate.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the defensive tactic. For example: https://d3fend.mitre.org/tactic/d3f:Isolate/.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the entity.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

process_entity.caption: Process Entity
process_entity.name: process_entity
process_entity.description: The Process Entity object provides critical fields for referencing a process.

cmd_line.caption: Command Line
cmd_line.description: The full command line used to launch an application, service, process, or job. For example: ssh user@10.0.0.10. If the command line is unavailable or missing, the empty string '' is to be used.

created_time.description: The time when the process was created/started.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The friendly name of the process, for example: Notepad++.

pid.caption: Process ID
pid.description: The process identifier, as reported by the operating system. Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: A unique identifier for this process assigned by the producer (tool).  Facilitates correlation of a process event with other events for that process.

cis_benchmark_result.description: The CIS Benchmark Result object contains information as defined by the Center for Internet Security (CIS) benchmark result. CIS Benchmarks are a collection of best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure.

desc.description: The CIS benchmark description.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The CIS benchmark name.

remediation.caption: Remediation Guidance
remediation.description: Describes the recommended remediation steps to address identified issue(s).

cwe.caption: CWE
cwe.name: cwe
cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.

caption.caption: Caption
caption.description: The caption assigned to the Common Weakness Enumeration unique identifier.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: URL pointing to the CWE Specification. For more information see CWE.

uid.caption: CWE ID
uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration unique number assigned to a specific weakness. A CWE Identifier begins "CWE" followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CWE-123.

device_hw_info.caption: Device Hardware Info
device_hw_info.name: device_hw_info
device_hw_info.description: The Device Hardware Information object contains details and specifications of the physical components that make up a device. This information provides an overview of the hardware capabilities, configuration, and characteristics of the device.

bios_ver.caption: BIOS Version
bios_ver.description: The BIOS version. For example: LENOVO G5ETA2WW (2.62).

chassis.caption: Chassis
chassis.description: The chassis type describes the system enclosure or physical form factor. Such as the following examples for Windows Windows Chassis Types

cpu_architecture.caption: CPU Architecture
cpu_architecture.description: The CPU architecture, normalized to the caption of the cpu_architecture_id value. In the case of Other, it is defined by the source.

cpu_architecture_id.caption: CPU Architecture ID
cpu_architecture_id.description: The normalized identifier of the CPU architecture.

1.caption: x86
1.description: CPU uses the x86 ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.

2.caption: ARM
2.description: CPU uses the ARM ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.

3.caption: RISC-V
3.description: CPU uses the RISC-V ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The CPU architecture is not mapped. See the cpu_architecture attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

cpu_bits.caption: CPU Bits
cpu_bits.description: The cpu architecture, the number of bits used for addressing in memory. For example: 32 or 64.

cpu_cores.caption: CPU Cores
cpu_cores.description: The number of processor cores in all installed processors. For Example: 42.

cpu_count.caption: CPU Count
cpu_count.description: The number of physical processors on a system. For example: 1.

cpu_speed.caption: Processor Speed
cpu_speed.description: The speed of the processor in Mhz. For Example: 4200.

cpu_type.caption: Processor Type
cpu_type.description: The processor type. For example: x86 Family 6 Model 37 Stepping 5.

desktop_display.caption: Desktop Display
desktop_display.description: The desktop display affiliated with the event

ram_size.caption: RAM Size
ram_size.description: The total amount of installed RAM, in Megabytes. For example: 2048.

uuid.caption: UUID
uuid.description: The device manufacturer assigned universally unique hardware identifier. For example: The BIOS System UUID or the Apple IOPlatformUUID.

d3f_tactic.caption: MITRE DEFEND™ Tactic
d3f_tactic.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated with a countermeasure.

d3f_technique.caption: MITRE DEFEND™ Technique
d3f_technique.description: The Technique object describes the technique ID and/or name associated with a countermeasure.

container.caption: Container
container.name: container
container.description: The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

hash.caption: Hash
hash.description: Commit hash of image created for docker or the SHA256 hash of the container. For example: 13550340a8681c84c861aac2e5b440161c2b33a3e4f302ac680ca5b686de48de.

image.caption: Image
image.description: The container image used as a template to run the container.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels associated to the container.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The container name.

network_driver.caption: Network Driver
network_driver.description: The network driver used by the container. For example, bridge, overlay, host, none, etc.

orchestrator.caption: Orchestrator
orchestrator.description: The orchestrator managing the container, such as ECS, EKS, K8s, or OpenShift.

pod_uuid.caption: Pod UUID
pod_uuid.description: The unique identifier of the pod (or equivalent) that the container is executing on.

runtime.caption: Runtime
runtime.description: The backend running the container, such as containerd or cri-o.

size.caption: Size
size.description: The size of the container image.

tag.caption: Image Tag
tag.description: The tag used by the container. It can indicate version, format, OS.

@deprecated.message: Use the labels or tags attribute instead.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the container.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The full container unique identifier for this instantiation of the container. For example: ac2ea168264a08f9aaca0dfc82ff3551418dfd22d02b713142a6843caa2f61bf.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

timespan.caption: Time Span
timespan.name: timespan
timespan.description: The Time Span object represents different time period durations. If a timespan is fractional, i.e. crosses one period, e.g. a week and 3 days, more than one may be populated since each member is of integral type. In that case type_id if present should be set to Other.

duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds
duration.description: The duration of the time span in milliseconds.

duration_days.caption: Duration Days
duration_days.description: The duration of the time span in days.

duration_hours.caption: Duration Hours
duration_hours.description: The duration of the time span in hours.

duration_mins.caption: Duration Minutes
duration_mins.description: The duration of the time span in minutes.

duration_months.caption: Duration Months
duration_months.description: The duration of the time span in months.

duration_secs.caption: Duration Seconds
duration_secs.description: The duration of the time span in seconds.

duration_weeks.caption: Duration Weeks
duration_weeks.description: The duration of the time span in weeks.

duration_years.caption: Duration Years
duration_years.description: The duration of the time span in years.

type.caption: Time Span Type
type.description: The type of time span duration the object represents.

type_id.caption: Time Span Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized identifier for the time span duration type.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: The Autonomous System details associated with an IP address.

intermediate_ips.caption: Intermediate IP Addresses
intermediate_ips.description: The intermediate IP Addresses. For example, the IP addresses in the HTTP X-Forwarded-For header.

proxy_endpoint.description: The network proxy information pertaining to a specific endpoint. This can be used to describe information pertaining to network address translation (NAT).

svc_name.description: The service name in service-to-service connections. For example, AWS VPC logs the pkt-src-aws-service and pkt-dst-aws-service fields identify the connection is coming from or going to an AWS service.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The network endpoint type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

12.description: A networking router.

14.caption: IPS
14.description: An intrusion prevention system.

15.caption: Load Balancer
15.description: A <a target='_blank' href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Load_balancing_(computing)'> Load Balancer device.

2.caption: Desktop
2.description: A desktop computer.

3.caption: Laptop
3.description: A laptop computer.

4.description: A tablet computer.

hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

instance_uid.caption: Instance ID
instance_uid.description: The unique identifier of a VM instance.

interface_name.description: The name of the network interface (e.g. eth2).

interface_uid.description: The unique identifier of the network interface.

ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the endpoint or was last logged into it.

subnet_uid.caption: Subnet UID
subnet_uid.description: The unique identifier of a virtual subnet.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the endpoint.

vpc_uid.caption: VPC UID
vpc_uid.description: The unique identifier of the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC).

zone.caption: Network Zone
zone.description: The network zone or LAN segment.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

namespace_pid.caption: Namespace PID

account.name: account
account.description: The Account object contains details about the account that initiated or performed a specific activity within a system or application. Additionally, the Account object refers to logical Cloud and Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) based containers such as AWS Accounts, Azure Subscriptions, Oracle Cloud Compartments, Google Cloud Projects, and otherwise.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the account (e.g. AWS Account ID , OCID , GCP Project ID , Azure Subscription ID , Google Workspace Customer ID , or M365 Tenant UID).

object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.

ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.

cost_center.caption: Cost Center
cost_center.description: The cost center associated with the user.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The timestamp when the user was created.

deleted_time.caption: Deleted Time
deleted_time.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.

email_addrs.caption: Email Addresses
email_addrs.description: A list of additional email addresses for the user.

employee_uid.caption: Employee ID
employee_uid.description: The employee identifier assigned to the user by the organization.

given_name.caption: Given Name
given_name.description: The given or first name of the user.

hire_time.caption: Hire Time
hire_time.description: The timestamp when the user was or will be hired by the organization.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The labels associated with the user. For example in AD this could be the userType, employeeType. For example: Member, Employee.

last_login_time.caption: Last Login
last_login_time.description: The last time when the user logged in.

ldap_cn.caption: LDAP Common Name
ldap_cn.description: The LDAP and X.500 commonName attribute, typically the full name of the person. For example, John Doe.

ldap_dn.caption: LDAP Distinguished Name
ldap_dn.description: The X.500 Distinguished Name (DN) is a structured string that uniquely identifies an entry, such as a user, in an X.500 directory service For example, cn=John Doe,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com.

leave_time.caption: Leave Time
leave_time.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location associated with a user. This is typically the user's usual work location.

manager.caption: Manager
manager.description: The user's manager. This helps in understanding an org hierarchy. This should only ever be populated once in an event. I.e. there should not be a manager's manager in an event.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.

office_location.caption: Office Location
office_location.description: The primary office location associated with the user. This could be any string and isn't a specific address. For example, South East Virtual.

phone_number.caption: Telephone Number
phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user. Corresponds to the LDAP Telephone-Number CN.

surname.caption: Surname
surname.description: The last or family name for the user.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the user.

raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

deleted_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.

hire_time_dt.caption: Hire Time
hire_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was or will be hired by the organization.

last_login_time_dt.caption: Last Login
last_login_time_dt.description: The last time when the user logged in.

leave_time_dt.caption: Leave Time
leave_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.

dns_query.caption: DNS Query
dns_query.name: dns_query
dns_query.description: The DNS query object represents a specific request made to the Domain Name System (DNS) to retrieve information about a domain or perform a DNS operation. This object encapsulates the necessary attributes and methods to construct and send DNS queries, specify the query type (e.g., A, AAAA, MX).

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The hostname or domain being queried. For example: www.example.com

opcode.caption: DNS Opcode
opcode.description: The DNS opcode specifies the type of the query message.

opcode_id.caption: DNS Opcode ID
opcode_id.description: The DNS opcode ID specifies the normalized query message type as defined in RFC-5395.

1.caption: Inverse Query
1.description: Inverse query, obsolete

2.caption: Status
2.description: Server status request

3.caption: Reserved
3.description: Reserved, not used

4.caption: Notify
4.description: Zone change notification

5.caption: Update
5.description: Dynamic DNS update

6.caption: DSO Message
6.description: DNS Stateful Operations (DSO)

99.caption: Other
99.description: The DNS Opcode is not defined by the RFC. See the opcode attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

class.caption: Resource Record Class
class.description: The class of resource records being queried. See RFC1035. For example: IN.

packet_uid.caption: Packet UID
packet_uid.description: The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.

type.caption: Resource Record Type
type.description: The type of resource records being queried. See RFC1035. For example: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, and NS.

control.caption: Security Control
control.description: A Control is prescriptive, prioritized, and simplified set of best practices that one can use to strengthen their cybersecurity posture. e.g. AWS SecurityHub Controls, CIS Controls.

version.caption: Version

created_time.description: The time when the certificate was created.

expiration_time.caption: Expiration Time
expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the certificate.

serial_number.description: The serial number of the certificate used to create the digital signature.

value.caption: Value
value.description: The value associated to the key.

values.caption: Values
values.description: Optional, the values associated to the key. You can populate this attribute, when you have multiple values for the same key.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

evidences.caption: Evidence Artifacts
evidences.name: evidences
evidences.description: A collection of evidence artifacts associated to the activity/activities that triggered a security detection.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: Describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity that triggered the detection.

api.caption: API Details
api.description: Describes details about the API call associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

connection_info.caption: Connection Info
connection_info.description: Describes details about the network connection associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

container.caption: Container
container.description: Describes details about the container associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

data.caption: Data
data.description: Additional evidence data that is not accounted for in the specific evidence attributes. Use only when absolutely necessary.

database.caption: Database
database.description: Describes details about the database associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

databucket.caption: Databucket
databucket.description: Describes details about the databucket associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

device.caption: Device
device.description: An addressable device, computer system or host associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint
dst_endpoint.description: Describes details about the destination of the network activity that triggered the detection.

email.caption: Email
email.description: The email object associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

file.caption: File
file.description: Describes details about the file associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

http_request.caption: HTTP Request
http_request.description: Describes details about the http request associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

http_response.caption: HTTP Response
http_response.description: Describes details about the http response associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

ja4_fingerprint_list.caption: JA4+ Fingerprints
ja4_fingerprint_list.description: Describes details about the JA4+ fingerprints that triggered the detection.

job.caption: Job
job.description: Describes details about the scheduled job that was associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The naming convention or type identifier of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, the @odata.type from Microsoft Graph Alerts V2 or display_name from CrowdStrike Falcon Incident Behaviors.

process.caption: Process
process.description: Describes details about the process associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

query.caption: DNS Query
query.description: Describes details about the DNS query associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

resources.caption: Cloud Resources
resources.description: Describes details about the cloud resources directly related to activity that triggered the detection. For resources impacted by the detection, use Affected Resources at the top-level of the finding.

script.caption: Script
script.description: Describes details about the script that was associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

src_endpoint.caption: Source Endpoint
src_endpoint.description: Describes details about the source of the network activity that triggered the detection.

tls.caption: TLS
tls.description: Describes details about the Transport Layer Security (TLS) activity that triggered the detection.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, the activity_id from CrowdStrike Falcon Alerts or behavior_id from CrowdStrike Falcon Incident Behaviors.

url.caption: URL
url.description: The URL object that pertains to the event or object associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

user.caption: User
user.description: Describes details about the user that was the target or somehow else associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

verdict.caption: Verdict
verdict.description: The normalized verdict of the evidence associated with the security detection.

verdict_id.caption: Verdict ID
verdict_id.description: The normalized verdict (or status) ID of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, Microsoft Graph Security Alerts contain a verdict enumeration for each type of evidence associated with the Alert. This is typically set by an automated investigation process or an analyst/investigator assigned to the finding.

1.caption: False Positive
1.description: The verdict for the evidence has been identified as a False Positive.

2.caption: True Positive
2.description: The verdict for the evidence has been identified as a True Positive.

3.caption: Disregard
3.description: The verdict for the evidence is that is should be Disregarded.

4.caption: Suspicious
4.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as Suspicious.

5.caption: Benign
5.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as Benign.

6.caption: Test
6.description: The evidence is part of a Test, or other sanctioned behavior(s).

7.caption: Insufficient Data
7.description: There is insufficient data to render a verdict on the evidence.

8.caption: Security Risk
8.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as a Security Risk.

9.caption: Managed Externally
9.description: The verdict for the evidence is Managed Externally, such as in a case management tool.

10.caption: Duplicate
10.description: This evidence duplicates existing evidence related to this finding.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

reg_key.caption: Registry Key
reg_key.description: Describes details about the registry key that triggered the detection.

reg_value.caption: Registry Value
reg_value.description: Describes details about the registry value that triggered the detection.

win_service.caption: Windows Service
win_service.description: Describes details about the Windows service that triggered the detection.

user.caption: User
user.name: user
user.description: The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal.

account.caption: Account
account.description: The user's account or the account associated with the user.

credential_uid.caption: User Credential ID
credential_uid.description: The unique identifier of the user's credential. For example, AWS Access Key ID.

domain.caption: Domain
domain.description: The domain where the user is defined. For example: the LDAP or Active Directory domain.

full_name.caption: Full Name
full_name.description: The full name of the person, as per the LDAP Common Name attribute (cn).

groups.caption: Groups
groups.description: The administrative groups to which the user belongs.

has_mfa.caption: MFA Assigned
has_mfa.description: The user has a multi-factor or secondary-factor device assigned.

ldap_person.caption: LDAP Person
ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The username. For example, janedoe1.

org.caption: Organization
org.description: Organization and org unit related to the user.

phone_number.caption: Telephone Number
phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user.

risk_level.caption: Risk Level
risk_level.description: The risk level, normalized to the caption of the risk_level_id value.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The risk level is not mapped. See the risk_level attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

risk_score.caption: Risk Score
risk_score.description: The risk score as reported by the event source.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of the user. For example, System, AWS IAM User, etc.

1.caption: User
1.description: Regular user account.

2.caption: Admin
2.description: Admin/root user account.

3.caption: System
3.description: System account. For example, Windows computer accounts with a trailing dollar sign ($).

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique user identifier. For example, the Windows user SID, ActiveDirectory DN or AWS user ARN.

uid_alt.caption: Alternate ID
uid_alt.description: The alternate user identifier. For example, the Active Directory user GUID or AWS user Principal ID.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

last_login_time.caption: Last Login
last_login_time.description: The last time when the user logged in.

last_login_time_dt.caption: Last Login
last_login_time_dt.description: The last time when the user logged in.

kill_chain_phase.caption: Kill Chain Phase
kill_chain_phase.name: kill_chain_phase
kill_chain_phase.description: The Kill Chain Phase object represents a single phase of a cyber attack, including the initial reconnaissance and planning stages up to the final objective of the attacker. It provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack. See Cyber Kill Chain®.

phase_id.caption: Kill Chain Phase ID
phase_id.description: The cyber kill chain phase identifier.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The kill chain phase is unknown.

1.caption: Reconnaissance
1.description: The attackers pick a target and perform a detailed analysis, start collecting information (email addresses, conferences information, etc.) and evaluate the victim’s vulnerabilities to determine how to exploit them.

2.caption: Weaponization
2.description: The attackers develop a malware weapon and aim to exploit the discovered vulnerabilities.

3.caption: Delivery
3.description: The intruders will use various tactics, such as phishing, infected USB drives, etc.

4.caption: Exploitation
4.description: The intruders start leveraging vulnerabilities to executed code on the victim’s system.

5.caption: Installation
5.description: The intruders install malware on the victim’s system.

6.caption: Command & Control
6.description: Malware opens a command channel to enable the intruders to remotely manipulate the victim's system.

7.caption: Actions on Objectives
7.description: With hands-on keyboard access, intruders accomplish the mission’s goal.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The kill chain phase is not mapped. See the phase attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

classification.description: The vendors classification of the Advisory.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the Advisory record was created.

install_state.description: The install state of the Advisory.

install_state_id.description: The normalized install state ID of the Advisory.

modified_time.description: The time when the Advisory record was last updated.

os.description: The operating system the Advisory applies to.

product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.

references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the vulnerabilities disclosed in the Advisory.

related_cves.caption: Related CVEs
related_cves.description: A list of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) identifiers related to the vulnerabilities disclosed in the Advisory.

related_cwes.caption: Related CWEs
related_cwes.description: A list of Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) identifiers related to the vulnerabilities disclosed in the Advisory.

size.description: The size in bytes for the Advisory. Usually populated for a KB Article patch.

src_url.description: The Advisory link from the source vendor.

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the Advisory.

uid.description: The unique number assigned to the disclosed vulnerability.

categories.description: The Website categorization names, as defined by category_ids enum values.

domain.description: The domain portion of the URL. For example: example.com in https://sub.example.com.

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The URL host as extracted from the URL. For example: www.example.com from www.example.com/download/trouble.

path.caption: Path
path.description: The URL path as extracted from the URL. For example: /download/trouble from www.example.com/download/trouble.

query_string.caption: HTTP Query String
query_string.description: The query portion of the URL. For example: the query portion of the URL http://www.example.com/search?q=bad&sort=date is q=bad&sort=date.

resource_type.caption: Resource Type
resource_type.description: The context in which a resource was retrieved in a web request.

scheme.caption: Scheme
scheme.description: The scheme portion of the URL. For example: http, https, ftp, or sftp.

subdomain.caption: Subdomain
subdomain.description: The subdomain portion of the URL. For example: sub in https://sub.example.com or sub2.sub1 in https://sub2.sub1.example.com.

url_string.caption: URL String
url_string.description: The URL string. See RFC 1738. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe. Note: The URL path should not populate the URL string.

architecture.description: Architecture is a shorthand name describing the type of computer hardware the packaged software is meant to run on.

cpe_name.caption: The product CPE identifier
cpe_name.description: The Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) name as described by (NIST) For example: cpe:/a:apple:safari:16.2.

epoch.caption: Epoch

purl.caption: Package URL
purl.description: A purl is a URL string used to identify and locate a software package in a mostly universal and uniform way across programming languages, package managers, packaging conventions, tools, APIs and databases.

remediation.description: Describes the recommended remediation steps to address identified issue(s).

osint.caption: OSINT
osint.name: osint
osint.description: The OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) object contains details related to an indicator such as the indicator itself, related indicators, geolocation, registrar information, subdomains, analyst commentary, and other contextual information. This information can be used to further enrich a detection or finding by providing decisioning support to other analysts and engineers.

answers.caption: Related DNS Answers
answers.description: Any pertinent DNS answers information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

attacks.caption: MITRE ATT&CK® Details
attacks.description: MITRE ATT&CK Tactics, Techniques, and/or Procedures (TTPs) pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: Any pertinent autonomous system information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

comment.caption: Analyst Comments
comment.description: Analyst commentary or source commentary about an indicator or OSINT analysis.

confidence.caption: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence of an indicator being malicious and/or pertinent, normalized to the caption of the confidence_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source or analyst.

confidence_id.caption: Confidence ID
confidence_id.description: The normalized confidence refers to the accuracy of collected information related to the OSINT or how pertinent an indicator or analysis is to a specific event or finding. A low confidence means that the information collected or analysis conducted lacked detail or is not accurate enough to qualify an indicator as fully malicious.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidence is not mapped to the defined enum values. See the confidence attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

email.caption: Related Email
email.description: Any email information pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

email_auth.caption: Related Email Authentication
email_auth.description: Any email authentication information pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

file.caption: Related File
file.description: Any pertinent file information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

kill_chain.caption: Kill Chain
kill_chain.description: Lockheed Martin Kill Chain Phases pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: Any pertinent geolocation information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

related_analytics.caption: Related Analytics
related_analytics.description: Any analytics related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

reputation.caption: Reputation Scores
reputation.description: Related reputational analysis from third-party engines and analysts for a given indicator or OSINT analysis.

script.caption: Related Script Data
script.description: Any pertinent script information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

signatures.caption: Related Digital Signatures
signatures.description: Any digital signatures or hashes related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The source URL of an indicator or OSINT analysis, e.g., a URL back to a TIP, report, or otherwise.

subdomains.caption: Related Subdomains
subdomains.description: Any pertinent subdomain information - such as those generated by a Domain Generation Algorithm - related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

subnet.caption: Related Subnet
subnet.description: A CIDR or network block related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

tlp.caption: Traffic Light Protocol
tlp.description: The Traffic Light Protocol was created to facilitate greater sharing of potentially sensitive information and more effective collaboration. TLP provides a simple and intuitive schema for indicating with whom potentially sensitive information can be shared.

AMBER.caption: TLP:AMBER
AMBER.description: TLP:AMBER is for limited disclosure, recipients can only spread this on a need-to-know basis within their organization and its clients. Note that TLP:AMBER+STRICT restricts sharing to the organization only. Sources may use TLP:AMBER when information requires support to be effectively acted upon, yet carries risk to privacy, reputation, or operations if shared outside of the organizations involved. Recipients may share TLP:AMBER information with members of their own organization and its clients, but only on a need-to-know basis to protect their organization and its clients and prevent further harm. Note: if the source wants to restrict sharing to the organization only, they must specify TLP:AMBER+STRICT.

AMBER STRICT.caption: TLP:AMBER+STRICT
AMBER STRICT.description: TLP:AMBER is for limited disclosure, recipients can only spread this on a need-to-know basis within their organization and its clients. Note that TLP:AMBER+STRICT restricts sharing to the organization only. Sources may use TLP:AMBER when information requires support to be effectively acted upon, yet carries risk to privacy, reputation, or operations if shared outside of the organizations involved. Recipients may share TLP:AMBER information with members of their own organization and its clients, but only on a need-to-know basis to protect their organization and its clients and prevent further harm. Note: if the source wants to restrict sharing to the organization only, they must specify TLP:AMBER+STRICT.

CLEAR.caption: TLP:CLEAR
CLEAR.description: TLP:CLEAR denotes that recipients can spread this to the world, there is no limit on disclosure. Sources may use TLP:CLEAR when information carries minimal or no foreseeable risk of misuse, in accordance with applicable rules and procedures for public release. Subject to standard copyright rules, TLP:CLEAR information may be shared without restriction.

GREEN.caption: TLP:GREEN
GREEN.description: TLP:GREEN is for limited disclosure, recipients can spread this within their community. Sources may use TLP:GREEN when information is useful to increase awareness within their wider community. Recipients may share TLP:GREEN information with peers and partner organizations within their community, but not via publicly accessible channels. TLP:GREEN information may not be shared outside of the community. Note: when “community” is not defined, assume the cybersecurity/defense community.

RED.caption: TLP:RED
RED.description: TLP:RED is for the eyes and ears of individual recipients only, no further disclosure. Sources may use TLP:RED when information cannot be effectively acted upon without significant risk for the privacy, reputation, or operations of the organizations involved. Recipients may therefore not share TLP:RED information with anyone else. In the context of a meeting, for example, TLP:RED information is limited to those present at the meeting.

WHITE.caption: TLP:WHITE
WHITE.description: TLP:WHITE and TLP:CLEAR may be used interchangeably, TLP:WHITE is the most up to date (as of TLP 2.0) usage.
